PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...  A Small Craft Advisory means that sustained wind speeds or frequent gusts of 25 to 33 kt and/or seas of 5 ft or higher are expected or occurring, and hazardous to small craft. Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller vessels, should avoid navigating in these conditions.  Registered app for 06405 Branford.
replyContent: Thank you for your feedback. The FEMA App amplifies alerts from local  authorities, such as the National Weather Service. To check if your location is set up to receive Small Craft Advisory alerts, first tap on your location in the Alerts section, and then scroll down to "Marine Weather" where you can opt in to Small Craft Advisory alerts.

Please FEMA, let ME decide what kinds of warnings to get! I live in Hawaii, and in the winter I get multiple daily alerts about High Surf Advisories and High Surf Warnings, which are useless to me. This causes me to ignore most FEMA alerts ("Oh, there it goes again. It's nothing."). I want to be alerted to tsunamis, earthquakes (since an earthquake in a neighbor island can cause a tsunami that will affect me), hurricanes, tropical storms, etc, but NOT High Surf. Please let me choose which kinds of warnings I want to receive. I have a weather radio in my office, and even it allows me to choose which alerts will cause it to beep. I am sure this would be a simple fix for your app. Thank you!
replyContent:
Hi Pat,
Our next update will allow you to choose the alerts that you receive. We will also be adding alerts for earthquakes and tsunamis. Thank you for the feedback.

FEMA could have hit a home run, but they didn't. As a volunteer who has been involved in disaster response and recovery for nearly forty years (including over 20 years as Secretary of  my State VOAD), I see some problems with the implementation of Disaster Reporter. The app itself is pretty good, but there are other problems with the way FEMA implemented this project.  Although the photos are almost certainly tagged with the location by the phone GPS when taken, that position information is not included in the data available via the FEMA Disaster Reporter website. The online FEMA map lacks many of the tools we all commonly expect in online maps, such as the ability to click on a point to "Center Map Here" and the ability to switch between a road map and a satellite view.  For many photographers, simply the fact that FEMA refuses to properly attribute their photos will be an issue.  The attribution problem arises mostly because FEMA chose not to require (or allow) users to "create an account in order to submit content."  It would have been trivially simple for the developers of the app to include the user's name (or other optional user chosen identifier) in the app.
